text:
February 7, 2017
Stephen Ostroff, M.D.
Acting Commissioner
Division of Dockets Management (HFA-305)
Food and Drug Administration
5630 Fishers Lane, Room 1061
Rockville, MD 20852
Re: Docket No. FDA-2016-N-2527Tobacco Product Standard for N-Nitrosonornicotine (NNN) Level in Finished Smokeless Tobacco Products, 82 Fed. Reg. 8,004 (Jan. 23, 2017)

Reducing cancer-producing NNN is the easiest thing I have ever done; Ive done it thousands of times.
Paraphrasing Mark Twain

We already have the prolonged federally unauthorized experimental paradigm and exegesis of light cigarettes, which clearly and convincingly testify to the fact that less nicotine in cigarettes translates into a higher risk for developing nicotine dependence and cancer. Light cigarettes are more zealously drawn upon, more deeply inhaled, retained in the lungs longer, and more often smoked down to the filter; in addition, more light cigarettes are smoked to achieve a comparable but temporary nicotine-induced focused, calm, and wellbeing cognitive result when compared to regular cigarettes, with the corresponding tobacco companies substantially increasing their revenue accordingly. It took a publication like The Clinical Management of Nicotine Dependence (1991) to serve as the legal substrate to the litany of lawsuits that followed.
Similarly, limiting NNN (N-nitrosonornicotine) in smokeless tobacco products is highly likely to further increase the incidence of nicotine dependence and cancer, while rallying the sales of light smokeless tobacco, thereby making smokeless tobacco product manufactures an even greater fortune.
It is just a matter of time before some addiction or healthy lifestyle guru publishes a comprehensive textbook on the clinical management of smokeless tobacco products (or the equivalent), and the smokeless tobacco product companies will not have the very deep pockets and the compellingly vast international following that helped tobacco companies survive and prosper.
The FDA might consider scrapping this NNN Docket to sculpt a newer one to include but not be limited to: 1) warning labels on all smokeless tobacco products; 2) new quit smokeless tobacco public service announcements and ads, channeled into the already existing quit smoking infrastructure; 3) mandatory health insurance, life insurance, Social Security, and disability urine NNN screens, with corresponding premium hikes or benefit depletions based on positive NNN results; 4) 30% food stamp (SNAP) allocations toward fresh fruit and 30% toward fresh vegetables to help prevent cancer born of systemic oxidative stress caused by NNN; and 5) suggestions to smokeless tobacco product manufacturers that they tool up for an alternative product production, such as beginning to annex themselves with pharmaceutical companies to help develop new inhaler delivery systems for certain established pharmaceutical products.
The money state and federal governments might lose from taxes of smokeless tobacco products and industries may be gained from pertinently stepping up insurance premiums, stepping down benefits, shortening hospital and long-term care stays, and prolonging productivity and spending.
This Docket should be scrapped in its entirety and resubmitted in a form that benefits all sides of the trade.
If you require additional information or have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me by email.
Respectfully submitted,

James A. Cocores, M.D.

Editor, The Clinical Management of Nicotine Dependence, Springer International

label: veryneg
docAbstract: Open

text:
As a physician, I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.
label: verypos
docAbstract: Open

text:
As an employee in the indoor tanning industry, I strongly oppose the FDAs proposal to ban tanning by minors and to require customers to sign a risk acknowledgement
form every six months. Our customers enjoy tanning for a variety of reasons, and for the reasons outlined below, no further government regulation is needed.

First, the decision of whether a minor should tan, be that outdoors in the sun or indoors at a tanning salon (that enforces limited tan times and other
safety precautions), is best left to parents, not the federal government. Most states already require parental consent for minors to tan indoors, ensuring the parent has input and approval.

In addition, we have many teenage clients who are referred to indoor tanning by their doctor or dermatologist to treat skin conditions. Why should these clients be
required to obtain these services at a dermatology office which is much more expensive than at an indoor tanning salon?


If minors are prohibited from using indoor tanning salons, they will instead use sunbeds at home, in an unregulated and unsupervised environment, and likely tan more
aggressively outdoors. These alternatives would lead to an increase in sunburn and injury, compared to tanning at our salons which enforce tan time limits and other safety precautions.


Next, requiring adults to sign a risk acknowledgement certification every six months in order to use a sunbed is absurd. Our customers
are already required to acknowledge risk before their first session; requiring this to be done every six months would be an administrative nightmare and tremendous burden to our salon employees, without serving any valid public purpose. There is no other product
or service in the country, including the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and red meat, that requires consumers to sign such a form. It would be unfair to require such a form in our business and not for the hundreds of products and services which present many
more dangers than UV exposure.

For all of these reasons, I am strongly opposed to these proposed additional regulations.

docAbstract: Open

text:
Responsible producers and veterinarians are the best people to make these decisions on the farm on a case by case basis. Oversight and regulation are needed to some extent to curb improper use. However, widespread and overly strict rules lead to animals that are not treated with necessary medications for fear of breaking rules. Veterinarians are trained to diagnose illness AND prescribe appropriate therapy. Producers and veterinarians feel as if their hands are tied when an appropriate medication could be used responsibly but is considered illegal because of labeling. Both veterinarians and producers are trained to observe appropriate withdrawal times and have the resources to find answers even if it is not stated on the label. We eat too! Our own families are consumers so we would not put them or our livelihood at risk knowingly using medications inappropriately.

There are programs like BQA and PQA that have improved animal welfare and producer knowledge. We do care about our animals. I encourage you to visit http://www.iabeef.org/on-the-farm/meet-a-cattle-farmer

Duration of therapy decisions should also be made by trained veterinarians familiar with the animals, caretakers, housing and end product being produced. Producers are responsible people wanting to operate a business and provide for their family. Over regulation will lead us down a path of animal welfare issues, sick animals being euthanized instead of treated and producers suffering economic losses.

Thank you for considering my thoughts

text:
These new technologies allow animal breeders the opportunities to repair harmful genetic disease causing mutations by restoring animals to their wild type genetic sequences.

These new regulations put significant barriers in the way of those efforts, the fundamental perspective of the animal itself as a "new animal drug" in those cases doesn't match the legal definition of a "new animal drug". I'm also very wary of the implications of classifying any genome as a drug.

FD&C 201(v)

(v) The term "new animal drug" means any drug intended for use for animals other than man, including any drug intended for use in animal feed but not including such animal feed,
(1) the composition of which is such that such drug is not generally recognized, among experts qualified by scientific training and experience to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of animal drugs, as safe and effective for use under the conditions prescribed, recommended, or suggested in the labeling thereof; except that such a drug not so recognized shall not be deemed to be a "new animal drug" if at any time prior to June 25, 1938, it was subject to the Food and Drug Act of June 30, 1906, as amended, and if at such time its labeling contained the same representations concerning the conditions of its use; or
(2) the composition of which is such that such drug, as a result of investigations to determine its safety and effectiveness for use under such conditions, has become so recognized but which has not, otherwise than in such investigations, been used to a material extent or for a material time under such conditions.
Provided that any drug intended for minor use or use in a minor species that is not the subject of a final regulation published by the Secretary through notice and comment rulemaking finding that the criteria of paragraphs (1) and (2) have not been met (or that the exception to the criterion in paragraph (1) has been met) is a new animal drug.

Section (1) states that drugs which are "generally recognized as safe" are not "new animal drugs". Clearly wildtype genes are generally recognized as safe and have been used to material extent and for material time regardless of the origins of the sequence. There is no fundamental difference between identical genetic sequences produced by evolution, selective breeding, random mutagenesis, or modern molecular technologies, therefore no fundamental difference in their risk profiles.

If the FDA is regulating in a risk-based, scientific manner then clearly regulating based on the method used to produce a sequence isn't the correct approach. Why would causing a genetic disease by radiation induced mutagenisis be assumed safe but reversing a disease causing mutation via modern molecular technologies be assumed unsafe? This revision is clearly not based on mitigating risks to people, animals or the environment.

Beyond that this approach creates the possibility for situations that can't be clearly regulated. For example, if a breeder repaired a genetic disease and restored an animal to it's natural genetic sequence that animal and it's offspring would be considered a drug. If the durg/animal were then bred to an animal of wild type with an identical gene sequence in the affected area, would the pups be legally drugs or not? The identical nature of the gene sequences of both parents makes it impossible to tell if they inherited it from the drug/parent or the non-drug parent.

if a genome edit is made using CRISPR, say a nucleotide is added then it's removed from the next generation by natural mutation or random mutagenisis is the regulated article gone and that second generation is not a drug?

If a genome edit is made to a male mammal on the Y chromosome will his daughters be drugs since they couldn't have inherited the change?

In the event of a deletion what exactly is the article, the missing nucleotides?

I have two general suggestions for different approaches that avoid some of these issues.

1. Regulate based on the risk not the breeding method, there is no scientific reason to bias regulations against modern breeding techniques in favor of older less exact methods.

2. If you must bias regulations against advance breeding methods make an exception for "restorative edits" or "genomic repair" where no novel sequences are introduced into a given species. Those genomic alterations that only transpose wild type sequences between animals within a single species. Since nothing novel is created other than gene flow within a species, it's risk profile is indistinguishable from selective breeding, so reasonably the genomes of those animals should have the same legal status. Considering there is an existing exemption for random mutagenisis despite its risks, this shouldn't be an issue, and it will allow breeders the freedom to use advanced techniques to repair the thousands of genetic diseases that have accumulated in our domestic animals because of the limits of selective breeding.

docAbstract: NMFS proposes to approve and implement measures included in Framework Adjustment 28 to the Atlantic Sea Scallop Fishery Management Plan, which the New England Fishery Management Council adopted and submitted to NMFS for approval.  The purpose of Framework 28 is to prevent overfishing, improve yield-per-recruit, and improve the overall management of the Atlantic sea scallop fishery.  Framework 28 would:  Set specifications for the scallop fishery for fishing year 2017, including days-at-sea allocations, individual fishing quotas, and sea scallop access area trip allocations; open the Elephant Trunk Flex Access Area to scallop fishing; and implement a 50 bushels of shell stock possession limit for limited access vessels inshore of the DAS demarcation line north of 42° 20’ N.

text: Attached are Bristol-Myers Squibb Company comments on the CMS proposed updates to the Medicaid National Drug Rebate Agreement.
label: neut
docAbstract:
This proposed notice with
comment period announces changes
that would be made to the Medicaid
National Drug Rebate Agreement
(NDRA) for use by the Secretary of the
Department of Health and Human
Services (HHS) and manufacturers
under the Medicaid Drug Rebate
Program (MDRP). We are updating the
NDRA to incorporate legislative and
regulatory changes that have occurred
since the agreement was published in
the February 21, 1991 Federal Register
(56 FR 7049). We are also updating the
NDRA to make editorial and structural
revisions, such as references to the
updated Office of Management and
Budget (OMB)-approved data collection
forms and electronic data reporting.

docAbstract: On April 6, 2015, we made a positive 90-day finding on the petition that the petitioned action may be warranted and conducted a status review of the species. After reviewing the best scientific and commercial data available, we have determined that the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s whale is taxonomically a subspecies of the Bryde’s whale, thus meeting the ESA’s definition of a species, and warrants listing as endangered under the ESA. We, therefore, are proposing to list the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s whale as an endangered species under the ESA.

text:
Because the Deepwater Horizon oil spill footprint included 48 percent of Bryde's whale habitat, an estimated 17 percent of the species was killed, 22 percent of reproductive females experienced reproductive failure, and 18 percent of the population likely suffered adverse health effects.
Bryde's whales measure up to 55 feet in length and weigh up to 30 tons.
Longline and shrimp trawl fisheries overlap with the Biologically Important Area of the Bryde's whale in the Gulf of Mexico.
The location of commercial shipping lanes, the difficulty of sighting a whale at the surface at night, and the low ability of large ships to change course quickly enough to avoid a whale elevate threats to Bryde's whales.
I strongly support the listing of this species as Endangered. Current protections for the Bryde's whale are insufficient.

text:
September 28, 2010

Donald Berwick, M.D.
Administrator
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services
Department of Health & Human Services
Attention: CMS-1406-IFC
Mail Stop C4-26-05
7500 Security Boulevard
Baltimore, MD 21244-1850

Re:File Code CMS -1498-IFC
Medicare Program; Hospital Inpatient Prospective Payment Systems for Acute Care Hospitals and the Long-Term Care Hospital Prospective Payment System Changes and FY 2011 Rates; Provider Agreements and Supplier Approvals; and Hospital Conditions of Participation for Rehabilitation and Respiratory Care Services; Medicaid Program: Accreditation for Providers of Inpatient Psychiatric Services

Dear Dr. Berwick:

We appreciate the opportunity to provide comments to CMS regarding the 3-day (or 1 day) DRG payment window policy change per the inpatient prospective payment system (IPPS) final rule published in the August 16, 2010 Federal Register.

3-Day (or 1 Day) Payment Window
Under the Preservation of Access to Care for Medicare Beneficiaries and Pension Relief Act of 2010, hospitals must include the diagnoses, procedures, and charges for all outpatient diagnostic and non-diagnostic services on the beneficiary’s inpatient stay if the services occurred on the day of, or the first, second, or third days immediately preceding the patient’s inpatient admission for subsection (d), or IPPS hospitals. The outpatient non-diagnostic services immediately preceding the day prior to the admission must be added to the inpatient claim for non-subsection (d) hospitals. If the non-diagnostic services do not relate to the inpatient stay, the hospital must attest that they are unrelated to the admission. CMS is to provide further guidance to hospitals on the attestation process. This policy change is effective for services provided on or after 6/25/2010.

We appreciate the opportunity to continue to unbundle services, but believe that some of the proposed controls are not necessary.

1)Per the FY 2011 IPPS final rule: “An outpatient service is related to the admission if it is clinically associated with the reason for a patient’s inpatient admission”. It would be helpful if CMS clearly defined “clinically associated” outpatient non-diagnostic services to avoid further confusion in the hospital community regarding unrelated outpatient non-diagnostic services. Also, we believe that any lack of clearly defined clinically associated services could cause confusion and more complications under post-review audits.
2)We strongly disagree with CMS’ proposal to implement an attestation process. Hospitals are currently required to bundle related services and we don’t believe that an attestation would provide additional value to the process. It would require additional administrative effort by hospital staff that doesn’t seem necessary as claims are required to be filed correctly under the law. If an attestation is required, the attestation process should be easy to follow and clearly defined: a) what is required in the medical record documentation to substantiate the service is unrelated; b) the format of the attestation; c) who must sign the attestation; and d) who is ultimately responsible for the attestation.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment and CMS’ consideration of our comments on the 3-day payment window interim final rule. If you have any questions please contact Teri Hills at (480) 301-4885 or me at (507) 284-4627.

Sincerely,

Ronald Grousky
Director, Medicare Strategy Unit

text:
As a physician, I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.

text:
Docket No. FDA-2015-N-1765

As an employee in the indoor tanning industry, I strongly oppose the FDAs proposal to ban tanning by minors and to require customers to sign a risk acknowledgement
form every six months. Our customers enjoy tanning for a variety of reasons, and for the reasons outlined below, no further government regulation is needed.

First, the decision of whether a minor should tan, be that outdoors in the sun or indoors at a tanning salon (that enforces limited tan times and other
safety precautions), is best left to parents, not the federal government. Most states already require parental consent for minors to tan indoors, ensuring the parent has input and approval.

In addition, we have many teenage clients who are referred to indoor tanning by their doctor or dermatologist to treat skin conditions. Why should these clients be
required to obtain these services at a dermatology office which is much more expensive than at an indoor tanning salon?


If minors are prohibited from using indoor tanning salons, they will instead use sunbeds at home, in an unregulated and unsupervised environment, and likely tan more
aggressively outdoors. These alternatives would lead to an increase in sunburn and injury, compared to tanning at our salons which enforce tan time limits and other safety precautions.


Next, requiring adults to sign a risk acknowledgement certification every six months in order to use a sunbed is absurd. Our customers
are already required to acknowledge risk before their first session; requiring this to be done every six months would be an administrative nightmare and tremendous burden to our salon employees, without serving any valid public purpose. There is no other product
or service in the country, including the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and red meat, that requires consumers to sign such a form. It would be unfair to require such a form in our business and not for the hundreds of products and services which present many
more dangers than UV exposure.

For all of these reasons, I am strongly opposed to these proposed additional regulations.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Open

text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.

docAbstract: On April 6, 2015, we made a positive 90-day finding on the petition that the petitioned action may be warranted and conducted a status review of the species. After reviewing the best scientific and commercial data available, we have determined that the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s whale is taxonomically a subspecies of the Bryde’s whale, thus meeting the ESA’s definition of a species, and warrants listing as endangered under the ESA. We, therefore, are proposing to list the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s whale as an endangered species under the ESA.

docAbstract: The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) of the United States Department of Agriculture is proposing to withdraw a final rule that was filed for public inspection by the Office of the Federal Register on January 19, 2017, in advance of publication, and that amends the Agency’s Horse Protection Act regulations (the 2017 HPA final rule).  On January 23, 2017, APHIS withdrew the 2017 HPA final rule from publication without undertaking notice and comment procedures, in accordance with a memorandum that was issued by the Executive Office of the President on January 20, 2017.  However, following a lawsuit, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit found this withdrawal to be deficient.  The District Court has indicated that one way to remedy this deficiency is to undertake notice and comment procedures on the proposed withdrawal.  APHIS is therefore proposing to withdraw the 2017 HPA final rule, and take public comment on this matter.  Comments on the withdrawal are due no later than August 21, 2023.

text:
As a physician, I am writing in strong support of Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) proposed rule titled, "General and Plastic Surgery Devices: Restricted Sale, Distribution, and Use of Sunlamp Products."

I commend the FDA on its leadership in regulating sunlamps and for taking this important step to protect the public health. It is estimated that indoor tanning causes upwards of 400,000 cases of skin cancer in the U.S. each year. In fact, using indoor tanning beds before age 35 can increase your risk of melanoma - the deadliest form of skin cancer - by 59% and the risk increases with each use.

I also support the FDA's proposed risk acknowledgement form that adults would have to sign before using tanning beds and booths. Quite a bit of misinformation exists on indoor tanning and some people think they are safe and beneficial. The FDA's efforts will help correct this misinformation and educate adults about the risks associated with indoor tanning.

Restricting teens' access to indoor tanning and educating all users about the dangers of tanning devices are critical steps to preventing skin cancer. Together with the FDA's final rule reclassifying sunlamp products and the proposed rule updating sunlamp performance standards, this proposed rule will make a significant impact in reducing the incidence of skin cancer in the U.S. I urge the FDA to finalize this proposed rule.
label: verypos

docAbstract: On September 15, 2016, the Sierra Club filed a complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, alleging that Gina McCarthy, in her official capacity as Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (“EPA”), failed to perform a non-discretionary duty to grant or deny within 60 days a petition submitted by Sierra Club on May 3, 2016 requesting that EPA object to a CAA Title V permit issued by the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (“PDEP”) for the Scrubgrass Generating Co., L.P. power plant (“Scrubgrass Plant”), located in Venango County, Pennsylvania.  The proposed consent decree would establish a deadline for EPA to take such action.

text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Exploring Industry Practices on Distribution and Display of Airline Fare, Schedule, and Availability Information

text: I am completely opposed to allowing voice calls on airplanes.  As a frequent business traveler, I welcome the peace and quiet we now have.  I do not want to be exposed to the business and personal conversations of others in such a confined space.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text: I am in favor of allowing voice calls before takeoff and after landing, but not during any flight, domestic or international.  Thank you.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
I believe the use of mobile wireless devices for voice calls is detrimental to the traveler and should be banned between the time the aircraft door is closed and the aircraft's landing. In February of 2014, when the DOT previously issued an Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking for the Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft, 97 percent of the commenters expressed opposition.

Pursuant to 49 U.S.C. 41712, DOT should find the use of mobile devices for voice during flight to be so disruptive that it would be inconsistent with adequate air transportation. Travel is difficult enough and the DOT should not add to traveler's misery. When it comes to flying on commercial airplanes in the United States, silence is golden.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Use of Mobile Wireless Devices for Voice Calls on Aircraft

text:
I have had an impossible time finding gluten free prescription medication when prescribed medication by a doctor. I urge the FDA to find a solution that at least provides some source of gluten free medications for common prescriptions.

Some manufacturers will provide the medication information sheet which has no information about whether the medication is gluten free or not. Some manufacturers will respond that the medication "does not contain wheat, rye, barley, or oats", but when asked about whether there is any cross contamination they do not provide any answer. Other manufacturers just respond that you should consult with your doctor or that they only provide the information directly to doctors. Another manufacturer answers that they "do not add gluten", but "cannot confirm that the product or any ingredients" are gluten free.

A lot of over the counter medication is labeled gluten free. It is rare in my experience for the manufacturer of a prescription medication to actually say that their medication is gluten free (2 so far).

Currently, for one medication I have been prescribed I am taking an over the counter alternative that I can find gluten free. For another, I have not been able to find a gluten free source at all, and with my doctor, we decided that the negative effects of possible exposure to gluten would be worse than the benefits gained from the medication.

Thank you for your time.
label: pos
docAbstract: closed

docAbstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is proposing to amend its medical regulations to permit full practice authority of all VA advanced practice registered nurses (APRNs) when they are acting within the scope of their VA employment. This rulemaking would increase veterans' access to VA health care by expanding the pool of qualified health care professionals who are authorized to provide primary health care and other related health care services to the full extent of their education, training, and certification, without the clinical supervision of physicians. This rule would permit VA to use its health care resources more effectively and in a manner that is consistent with the role of APRNs in the non-VA health care sector, while maintaining the patientcentered, safe, high-quality health care that veterans receive from VA. The proposed rulemaking would establish additional professional qualifications an individual must possess to be appointed as an APRN within VA. The proposed rulemaking would subdivide APRN's into four separate categories that include certified nurse practitioner, certified registered nurse anesthetist, clinical nurse specialist, and certified nurse-midwife. The proposed rulemaking would also provide the criteria under which VA may grant full practice authority to an APRN, and define the scope of full practice authority for each category of APRN. VA intends that the services to be provided by an APRN in one of the four APRN roles would be consistent with the nursing profession's standards of practice for such roles.

text: PLEASE establish the Puget Sound as a No Discharge Zone. We need to prohibit the discharge of sewage from commercial and recreational boats in Puget Sound, whether treated or not. We know boaters don't want to pollute, but we need clear and enforceable rules to ensure proper waste disposal for all.  The Puget Sound needs all the help it can get, it is already much too polluted as it is!

text: As a citizen of Puget Sound, I believe that the NDZ is a critical step to protect our waterways from degradation, recover endangered species and protect human health. Puget Sound bears the burden of pollution from many sources. No Discharge Zones across the country have been highly successful in protecting waterways. It's past time to grant the Sound this important and common-sense protection.

text:
To: Joel Salter, EPA Region 10
From: Gerald Joyce, Consultant/Owner, Moon Joyce Resources
Subject: Support for Washington State Department of Ecology Prohibition of Discharges of Vessel Sewage; Receipt of Petition and Preliminary Affirmative Determination [FRL-9954-99-Region 10]
I support EPA's preliminary affirmative determination that sufficient pumpout facilities and capacity exist to serve boater needs within the No Discharge Zone (NDZ) proposed for Puget Sound and the fresh waters of Lake Washington and Lake Union.
As a marine biologist, I have traveled on ships of many nationalities around the world and have met a variety of regulations. One is the equivalent to the US No Discharge Zone. In all cases, the ships had been retrofitted with small sewage holding tanks with very little trouble. Certainly vessels in Puget Sound, with the five-year implementation schedule, can easily comply with the requirements of a no discharge zone. Although there are objections from some small commercial vessels, they have small crews that produce small volumes of sewage. With the high number of pumpout stations, including one being prepared at the Port of Seattle's Pier 69 in Elliot Bay, a small commercial vessel should have no problem retrofitting its toilets with small holding tanks. Other large vessels should also have little problem adapting to these regulations.
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this preliminary affirmative determination. If you have any questions, please contact me at Jerry_j@msn.com.
label: pos

text:
Reject a Puget Sound-wide No Discharge Zone petition by Washington's Department of Ecology

- Raw sewage discharge is already illegal within 3 miles of shore - which is almost everywhere in Puget Sound. If there are sensitive areas spend the effort identifying them to the public.
- There are plenty of convenient pump out stations getting plenty of use as pacific north-westerners genuinely and widely support water quality. I boat in the Gig Harbor, Henderson Bay, Tacoma, and Vashon area. I know of 6 different pump out stations, 4 of which are attended (at fuel stations) where I don't even have to lift a finger - they do it for me!
- USCG-approved type I and type II Marine Sanitation Devices (MSDs), would be outlawed by the proposed NDZ. Again, this is just plan bad regulation - these devices do not cause water quality issues.

Instead - address the much bigger issue - billions of gallons of raw sewage dumped by Victoria, B.C. as well as King County METRO and Seattle Public Utilities when there are storm overflows. Also, as a public works contractor, I know that throughout the region, storm sewers flow directly into Puget Sound, Lake Union, and Lake Washington, often without even being interrupted by a fuel water separator. These same storm sewers also carry the untreated waste pets - pets that outnumber boaters significantly.

Even the treated sewage being discharged by municipalities deserves more attention. The Seattle Time reported on 2/23/2016 that Puget Sound fish were found with detectable levels of prescription drugs not removed by water treatment standards. http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/environment/drugs-flooding-into-puget-sound-and-its-salmon/ Why isn't this a priority?

This petition is a mis-direction of efforts to help water quality.

Meredith Daniels, Gig Harbor, WA
label: veryneg

text:
To tackle the contributing insult that comes from boats discharging into the vital waters of Puget Sound, please approve the Puget Sound No Discharge Zone, a designated area where the discharge of sewage (black water/toilet waste) from boats, whether treated or not, is prohibited.

If a no-discharge zone is established, no boat, whether a freighter, a cruise ship or a sailboat will be allowed to discharge waste anywhere within the designated zone. The zone basically extends from the Canadian border, through the San Juan Islands to the southern reaches of Puget Sound.

Sewage from boats affects our lakes, bays and beaches. That sewage includes bacteria, viruses and pathogens, and emerging chemicals of concern that can close shellfish beds and make humans sick.

We are collectively working hard to recover shellfish beds and keep our beaches clean for swimming and recreation, which is why a no-discharge zone is a priority of the Puget Sound Partnership Action Plan. Surprisingly, our Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) region is the only region in the country where these types of zones have not yet been established.

There are 90 no-discharge zones in 26 states. And not one in our precious waters that we've spent so much effort and money to protect.

In Puget Sound, we have more than the required amount of pump-out capacity for recreational and commercial vessels with both pump-out stations on docks, mobile pump-out boats and trucks.

As to the onboard sewage-treatment systems on most boats they do not adequately protect water quality and public health.

The social, cultural and economic value of the shellfish harvest in Puget Sound whether it's tribal, recreational or commercial is enormous. And it is a deep part of our heritage.

The shellfish industry has an annual value of $184 million. And while tourism and recreation also play a central role in our local economies, they all require the same essential ingredient: clean water. While pollution makes its way into the Sound in various ways, a no-discharge zone will help solve a discrete part of this complex equation.

As we think about protection in a world where the population is growing but the geography isn't, we might ask, is the system too big to fail? We must begin to tackle the multiple insults to this stunningly beautiful chemical and biological system.

The Salish Sea is part of the economic engine of the state, the source of communal pride, our shared vernacular and a spiritual, hallowed ground.

Let's think ahead. Let's stop dumping. We can do this. It is 2016. It's time to designate a no-discharge zone to protect our sensitive resources in Puget Sound.

I've copied most of this message from an op-ed. I agree with its contents.
label: verypos

text:
I have been fishing off the coast of San Diego for over 40 years and have owned my own off shore boat since 2004. I believe my fishing skills are okay. Only the past 2 years has there have been a rare number of Bluefin Tuna in our local waters. Although I specifically targeted them this year I was one of numerous private boaters that did not even get a strike although dozens if not hundreds of 80 plus pound Bluefin Tuna were crashing all around my boat. They were close enough I probably could have touched them. Although I spent hundreds of dollars on fuel and bait I was skunked The three separate times I went out. It was not for lack of effort. I have talked to several fisherman who had the same luck. Like myself many others tried their luck a few times and gave up due to the Bluefins finicky bite.

In reading the fishing reports, seeing only a rare few fishermen landing a Bluefin Tuna is a more accurate view on the subject. When a commercial charter boat goes out with a 23 passenger load and only a hand full of fisherman hook and land a Bluefin tuna how can that compare to large seiners and long line commercial fishing that are raping the ocean.

As I mentioned above, I have been fishing on my own boat for 12 years and have caught less than 6 Bluefin Tuna over that time period. This is a more common story than your study reflects.

Private fisherman are not the problem.

text:
I am recreational fisherman and I oppose the listing of the Pacific bluefin tuna as endangered. The result of this ESA listing is important to me.

While the population of Pacific bluefin tuna has, in recent decades, declined to historic levels, the species is not in danger of extinction. The United States Government, NOAA, and the international organizations responsible for management of this pelagic species, the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) and the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC), took action several years ago to reduce fishing pressure and conserve stocks. The most recent scientific data demonstrates that these international conservation efforts to improve Pacific bluefin tuna stocks have been successful in stabilizing the global population and stocks have already begun the rebuilding process.

Thank you for considering my comments.

text:
I oppose the destruction of bats and their habitat by gas and oil companies, as is being considered by the Service. I oppose the development of a proposal for an "Incidental Take Permit" and advocate that an Environmental Impact Statement provide comprehensive analysis of alternative actions that will not allow the taking of bats.

Chesapeake, MarkWest, Williams, Anthero Resources, Ascent Resources, Southwestern, EQT, EnLink Midstream, MPLX, Marathon Petroleum, and Rice Energy are companies that routinely infringe on these species through gas and oil exploration and development activities. The continuation of their projects will result in continuing harm due to the unavoidable impacts entailed in this development, despite the promise of a Habitat Conservation Plan to be developed through the upcoming EIS process. This is especially true considering the cumulative impact of allowing this destruction over a 50 year period.

The Scope for the EIS must examine the impacts that accompany oil and gas development including water withdrawal and depletion, toxic waste generation and disposal, land changes that result in habitat loss and fragmentation, water contamination and air pollution, and the emission of greenhouse gases that exacerbate climate change. These are known to affect the roosting and foraging ecology of bats, particularly during critical life periods (e.g., hibernation, migration, and reproduction) (Hein, C. D. 2012). Bats are known to have low reproductive rates and respond slowly to rapid population declines (Barclay and Harder 2005).The devastation of White-nose Syndrome has resulted in a stunning decline of nearly 98% of hibernating bat populations in Pennsylvania (Turner et al. 2011). This disease and the effects of other human activities that degrade and destroy suitable habitat and resources are compounding challenges that bats must already withstand (Kunz and Parsons 2009). Bats are struggling to survive here; these takings could be the final blow for some species.

Bats are critical to our economy and ecology. For instance, worldwide, bats function as pollinators, seed dispersers, and biological controls for nocturnal insects (Kunz and Parsons 2009) (Jones et al. 2009). In Pennsylvania, Ohio, and West Virginia, most species consume large quantities of night-flying insects, many of which are agricultural and forest pests. (Hein, C. D. 2012). Their loss will be our loss.

I oppose the consideration and proposal of an Incidental Take Permit for bats and oppose the consideration of the reduction of the protections now in place for bats in these locations for any period of time. All five of these bat species are in need of more effective protections in the face of the multiple challenges they already must contend with so they may continue to be a critically beneficial part of the regional ecosystem.

text:
When I book travel, I often use comparison websites to search and purchase airline tickets. I rely on the convenience of finding all my options on one screen. Plus, when airlines know their fares will be listed next to their competitors, they will be more likely to offer a competitive price.

It's come to my attention that some airlines are trying to make it harder for me to see all my options by restricting certain websites from publishing fare and schedule information. They shouldn't get to pick and choose who can share information that's already publicly available. We need more transparency in the marketplace, not less.
label: veryneg
